TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract sealed ContextMenuService extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Provides the system implementation for displaying a .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService> class provides attached properties that can be used to specify the appearance and position of a context menu. Many of the properties in the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService> class are also defined by the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenu>. Sometimes it is more convenient to set the properties by using the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService> class than by setting the properties on a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenu>. For example, you can create a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenu> to be shared by multiple elements, but use the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService> class to specify a different position of the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenu> for each element. The following properties are defined by the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenu> and <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService> classes. If any of these properties are set on both <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenu> and the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService>, the property value from the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService> is used.
- <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService.Placement%2A>
- <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService.PlacementRectangle%2A>
- <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService.PlacementTargetProperty>
- <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService.HorizontalOffset%2A>
- <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService.VerticalOffsetProperty>
- <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService.HasDropShadow%2A>
You can also use the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService> to display menus on disabled items.
## Examples The following example assigns the same <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenu> to two buttons and sets the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService.HasDropShadow%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService.Placement%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService.PlacementRectangle%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService.HorizontalOffset%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenu.VerticalOffset%2A> properties to set the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenu> to different positions for each button.
[!code-xaml[ContextMenuService_snip#SharedContextMenu](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/ContextMenuService_snip/CSharp/Pane1.xaml#sharedcontextmenu)]
The following example shows how to use the service to display a <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenu> on a disabled button. Notice that you set the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.ContextMenuService.ShowOnDisabled%2A> property on the button that is the parent of the context menu.
[!code-xaml[ContextMenu#3](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/ContextMenu/CSharp/Pane1.xaml#3)]
